history.content:
REDACTED (Sorry. I don't know how I missed the entirety of the third and fourth sentences. My mistake. Best of luck!)

SO incorrect^

The OP mentioned that it is a class in distributed systems.

I am going to assume (maybe incorrectly) that you want to declare L&S CS and this class is either CS61A, CS61B, or CS70. If that is the case, look at @3105.

I am going to assume (maybe incorrectly) that you want to declare L&S CS and this class is either CS61A, CS61B, or CS70. If that is the case, look at @3105.

children.subject: We are on the same boat and I believe many others also suffer from this lose-lose situation. Sad.

I don't know a lot about grad school admissions, but I empathise with your problems, and hope they get resolved soon. I can only say that, at the end of the day, the people evaluating grad school applications are human beings who will certainly take into account extenuating circumstances such as yours while evaluating your application - so long as you mention it on your app somewhere, explaining your bad grade, it hopefully should not matter (you may want to speak to a prof here for better guidance, though).
I don't know your specific situation, but you could look into getting an Incomplete, and finishing it next semester. You'd want to talk to your adviser either way.

history.content:
Hello everyone,

I am in a situation where I'll probably do poorly in one of my classes. This is due to family issues that were beyond my control. Well, I am doing poorly in a class, and perhaps a class I am interested in going to grad school for. I am interested in distributed systems and I was wondering if I am taking a class in that field, whether failing to retake it or getting a low B or C would be better? It's unfortunate that the class I am being affected the most by is this class. Will I even have a shot at getting to grad school with either of those situation, or am I in a lose-lose situation?
history.subject: Better to fail class  and retake or get a low B or C?
